text: So sorry Arianne. Condolences.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Hah, you were my #1 suspect.
author: GraphicMatt

text: At Wednesday’s Civic Appointments Committee meeting, Councillor Mike Layton’s attempt to appoint a mystery candidate to the TTC board was defeated by allies of Mayor John Tory.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Councillor Gord Perks compares the provincial subway upload to Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle. https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2019/03/21/mayors-executive-committee-wants-province-to-release-subway-upload-advice.html …
author: GraphicMatt

text: Yeah, I think that’s a good point in favour of making the change. But minor property tax increase would have been a more direct/faster (and, importantly, stable) way to achieve same revenue. (And also would have resulted in owners of $3 million homes paying more.)
author: GraphicMatt

text: Charging people who buy $3 million houses in Toronto more land transfer tax is a fine idea, but worth noting the ~$5 million this is estimated to raise could also be achieved by a 0.2% residential tax increase.
author: GraphicMatt

text:
That there’s still no firm definition for what a “subway upload” actually means is pretty mind-blowing at this point.

So far, the Queen’s Park plan is basically:

1) Give us the subways
2) ???
3) More subways
author: GraphicMatt

text: Program is limited to households making less than $120K a year — hard to buy a million dollar home with that income.
author: GraphicMatt

text: I am limited to the options the newsletter service provides, but you could use my PayPal link to send me the cost of an annual subscription ($50) and I will give you access, if you’d prefer to do things that way. Glad you’re interested!
author: GraphicMatt

text: Thanks Janet! Hope you dig it.
author: GraphicMatt

text: It’s neat to see evidence of the success of an event/activation in data like this.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Give @Diane_Dyson the prize. She wrote in to point out it coincided with a @thereadingline #BookRide event.
author: GraphicMatt

text: In this week’s @cityhallwatcher, I asked people to write in with theories as to why Sunday, August 26 between 2 and 2:15 p.m. was the highest non-weekday ridership period for the Bloor bike lanes recorded last year.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Awesome — I’m not sure why this 253-day-old post resurfaced yesterday, but I’m glad for the update!
author: GraphicMatt

text: In related news: there are now 3,064 messages opposing the subway upload attached to tomorrow’s Executive Committee agenda item. http://app.toronto.ca/tmmis/viewAgendaItemHistory.do?item=2019.EX3.1 …
author: GraphicMatt

text: An insta-subscribe for me.
author: GraphicMatt

text: No matter who owns the subway, building “more, faster, better” will require someone to step up and spend billions of dollars. The province has given no real indication that they’re prepared to do that.
author: GraphicMatt

text: (The Terms of Reference document between the city/province just lays out a framework for negotiations.)
author: GraphicMatt

text: Councillor Michael Ford writes a Toronto Sun op-ed supporting his uncle’s subway upload. He says the Terms of Reference document “describes how we can build more, faster, better — breaking the gridlock that is choking our city” but it.. does not do that.
author: GraphicMatt

text: I’ve been playing around with the mortgage qualification calculator on RateHub - max mortgage for a household making $120K with 5% down is $540Kish. Depending on interest rates, etc.
author: GraphicMatt

text: From the CBC article Mark linked: “The budget is far from clear on how much the buyer would owe; is it the same dollar amount the CMHC provided up front, or does the bill go up based on how much the house has appreciated in value?” Details before the program launches in September
author: GraphicMatt

text: Not new home only, but new homes can get 10%, while existing is only 5%.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Here’s what the federal budget says on the bigger incentive for buying new construction: “could help encourage the home construction needed to address some of the housing supply shortages in Canada, particularly in our largest cities.”
author: GraphicMatt

text: Missed this on first read re: first-time home buyer’s incentive. Bigger incentives if people are buying new construction — 5% for existing, 10% for new. Interesting policy choice.
author: GraphicMatt

text: For Toronto, this federal budget doesn’t seem to offer much in the way of new direct investment, though there are a bunch of programs and funds that COULD translate into funds sometime later. The waiting game continues.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Nothing specific on any Toronto transit funding in the budget. Municipalities are getting an extra $2.2 billion “top-up” for infrastructure from the gas tax, but how that’d translate to dollars for Toronto remains TBD. It won’t work to a whole lot of $$$.
author: GraphicMatt

text: CRA getting $50 million to look for, among other things, flippers who aren’t reporting all their income, with focus on BC and Ontario. They expect to turn a profit after nabbing these scofflaws.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Federal $2.2-billion “Reaching Home” program to reduce homelessness will launch April 1, provided this isn’t an elaborate April Fools joke. The city will hope this includes the $45 million in federal money they’ve budgeted for shelter services.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Fed budget defends “stress test” rules for mortgages, with chart showing the number of people getting mortgage loans greater than 450% of their income has declined pretty sharply.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Will need to do the math on what kind of mortgage you could qualify for on $120K household income these days, and how that’d translate in terms of unit size in T.O.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Here’s the “how it works” of the new First Time Home Buyer Incentive. If your household income is below $120K a year and you’re buying your first home, you can apply to get 10% of the purchase price covered by CMHC, repayable when you sell.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Of minor note because they can’t bind future governments, but they might as well try: the Liberals say they’ll introduce legislation requiring the federal government to maintain a National Housing Strategy.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Also, inevitably: an expert panel on housing.
author: GraphicMatt

text:
There’s also going to be a Housing Supply CHALLENGE for municipalities. Hope we win!

“The Housing Supply Challenge will invite municipalities and other stakeholder groups across Canada to propose new ways to break down barriers that limit the creation of new housing.”
author: GraphicMatt

text: Budget 2019: $10 billion over nine years for the Rental Construction Financing Program that provides loans for construction of affordable rental housing. They say it’ll create 42,500 units across Canada. (John Tory pledged to create 40,000 just in Toronto over next 12 years)
author: GraphicMatt

text:
Federal budget: “Housing markets are undergoing an orderly correction, though affordability challenges remain in Toronto
and Vancouver.” Orderly!
author: GraphicMatt

text: 2 million trees to be planted along the Highway of Heroes between Trenton and Toronto. The feds are kicking in some extra cash over the next three years.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Amount you can take out of an RSP for the Home Buyers’ Plan will increase from $25,000 to $35,000. Alex and Michelle from Toronto are excited about this. (My budget analysis always begins by searching for ‘Toronto.’ Now you know my secrets.)
author: GraphicMatt

text: Here’s a pdf of the 2019 federal budget — it’s 7MB, so be warned. https://www.budget.gc.ca/2019/docs/plan/budget-2019-en.pdf … (PDF)
author: GraphicMatt

text:
A fresh @cityhallwatcher was posted yesterday and hey it’s free this week. 

If you dig it, I’d love it if you’d subscribe.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Or: Analysis as a gif. https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/what-toronto-needs-from-the-federal-budget-1.5061352 …
author: GraphicMatt

text: My @cbctoronto column: The Trudeau government will release their 2019 federal budget today! Here’s what Toronto is looking for: money. And also: more money. The city is short billions for transit and housing. https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/what-toronto-needs-from-the-federal-budget-1.5061352 … #TOpoli #cdnpoli
author: GraphicMatt

text: I’ve only been in this email journalism game for a couple of months, but there are few things more satisfying than finally getting to close a bunch of tabs once a newsletter goes out.
author: GraphicMatt

text:
Check Your Inbox: @cityhallwatcher #10 is on the way.

FREE this week. You get stories about:

- Toronto’s vanishing retail jobs
- A million cyclists on Bloor
- Vision Zero on the Danforth

& more!

Try it and subscribe if you enjoy: $5 a month!

https://graphicmatt.substack.com/p/city-hall-watcher-10-toronto-employment …

#TOpoli
author: GraphicMatt

text: That’s a good point I hadn’t considered. No idea how that would even be possible, really. Any ideas on SRT and the AODA, @SwanBoatSteve?
author: GraphicMatt

text:
The issue with this sort of statement is it’s true on a single year basis — raising property taxes in 2019 wouldn’t immediately improve city’s housing situation. 

But what if the city had created a revenue stream by raising them a bit every year starting in 2014?
author: GraphicMatt

text: Mayor John Tory says he doesn’t think the city would be able to do more to get people into affordable housing if he raised property taxes, citing “the capacity of the industry to actually produce” housing units. http://www.postcity.com/Eat-Shop-Do/Do/February-2019/Mayor-Tory-talks-Torontos-homelessness-crisis/ …
author: GraphicMatt

text: The process for snow removal on the elevated part of the Scarborough RT route is bananas.
author: GraphicMatt

text: Good piece on the history and current state the Scarborough RT in the Toronto Sun. I remain very curious to learn how the TTC will keep this line running until 2026 (or, likely, later). https://torontosun.com/news/local-news/old-scarborough-rt-just-not-up-to-winter-weather …
author: GraphicMatt
